dialogue_history.content:
Analyze this financial news and estimate stock price movement probabilities.
Company: Apple Inc. (AAPL)
News Headline: 'Magnificent 7,' crypto, Trump coin, AI, Trump, tariffs, Fed, and everything else that will dominate Davos
News Content: This is The Takeaway from today's Morning Brief, which you can sign up to receive in your inbox every morning along with:

The chart of the day What we're watching What we're reading Economic data releases and earnings

Coverage of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, each year is something I view as a competitive sport.

I actually start training for the intense week over the summer, as my few close friends know (and yes, they all make fun of me). The number of workouts every week in the lead-up rises incrementally so I can easily sprint up and down the two-mile promenade with a backpack to stuff in as many meetings as humanly possible (yes, I do this).

My one cheat meal a week gets replaced by green drinks and extra doses of vitamins to ensure I don't get sick. I meditate twice a day and carefully pick out clothes I know will help me execute at the highest level. Look good, feel good, good things happen.

To me, this one event is the closest I will get to being like Michael Jordan in the playoffs — and I am very lucky to be in attendance.

And this year, the gathering of the elites flying in on private jets to wax poetic on the world's biggest problems will be extra nutty.

Read more: Here are the biggest global risks for 2025

The conference unofficially kicks off on Trump's Inauguration Day. Some CEOs I know who normally would be at Davos all week are dropping in mid-week after working the inauguration party rounds. By Tuesday, the newly minted president may have uncorked a host of executive orders that could impact the businesses of the top CEOs on the ground. And, of course, impact the global markets.

This is why this year's WEF will be more important than the norm for you, the average investor. The headlines will be coming in hot and heavy as CEOs look to challenge Trump or get on his good side. They will also look to talk up their businesses ahead of the start of earnings season, and with markets getting a little rockier of late.

Here's what yours truly and our very own Jennifer Schonberger will be watching while bundled up in five layers all week. Be sure to bookmark the "streaming now" section on Yahoo Finance to catch all our market-moving interviews in real time. Or tune in where you normally catch us, whether that's on Samsung TV or our nifty app.

Unlike our previous trips to Davos over the past decade, I will be taping several special episodes of the Opening Bid podcast on the ground. I could tell you who those guests will be, but where is the fun in that? Best to be surprised!

Story Continues

Now, on to that guide...

Big bank CEOs: The biggest names in banking, such as JPMorgan (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon, Bank of America (BAC) CEO Brian Moynihan, Goldman Sachs (GS) CEO David Solomon, Citi (C) CEO Jane Fraser, and Morgan Stanley (MS) CEO Ted Pick will be in attendance. While this group will all get asked about Trump policies, it's going to be their outlook on interest rates that will be most key to market sentiment. Most have not spoken publicly since the Fed signaled a likely halt in rate cuts last month, and they will want to be heard ahead of the Fed's Jan. 28-29 policy meeting.

The tariff CEOs: Retail will have a nice showing at Davos, with the CEOs of Polo Ralph Lauren (RL), Williams Sonoma (WSM), and Gap (GAP) (their CEO's first time at the event) making the rounds. These companies are right in the middle of the tariff debate. I'll be interested in how they are preparing for Trump tariffs from a supply chain perspective. I am also interested in how much they could raise prices post-tariffs — it could offer valuable insight into the 2025 inflation outlook and Fed policy.

Read more: How do tariffs work, and who really pays them?

The race to catch Nvidia: It will be another year of artificial intelligence chatter throughout the halls of Davos. This time, I think the discussions will take two forms. First, unlike last year, where the AI discussions were mostly about potential, investors are going to want to see clear lines to revenue and profits. So I encourage AI CEOs to bring it. And two, we will probably hear more about how Big Tech players in Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet (GOOGL) are aiming to develop their own high-powered AI chips to catch Nvidia (NVDA), or at least make good enough chips to diversify. Leaders from OpenAI and Anthropic will also be in attendance, and their thoughts on chips could be key. I'll be watching Nvidia's stock price like a hawk this week, and you should be as well.

Crypto delegation: The crypto industry has had a solid presence at Davos in the past five years. This year, the industry is expected to be out in force, headlined by an appearance from Coinbase (COIN) CEO Brian Armstrong. I'll be quite attuned to what the crypto crowd thinks about the latest volatility in bitcoin, MicroStrategy's (MSTR) bitcoin buying binge, what they are hearing from the pro-crypto Trump administration, and early assessments on Paul Atkins as the likely next SEC chairman.

And of course, the new Trump coin that debuted to much fanfare (and market cap) on Friday.

The token quickly rose to a market cap of $73 billion in about 48 hours, surpassing DOGE as the largest meme coin so far.

The market cap of the crypto has since dropped to $12 billion from its launch, according to CoinMarketCap.

Stocks: Stocks are beginning to look top-heavy (especially the Magnificent 7), as I have reported. I'm eager to hear from market pros such as JPMorgan's Mary Erdoes and economic experts like Nouriel Roubini on whether they are seeing red flags on the horizon. Any calls they make at this Davos may hold greater weight given more volatile market conditions and increased Trump policy uncertainty.

The political wild cards: As of this writing, contacts have told me President-elect Donald Trump plans to send delegates to Davos. Who precisely gets the nod is the wild card. (I fancy it will be potential Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick, a Davos party scene regular for many years. Elon has long hated Davos, so hard to see him appearing). Trump himself is slated to give a speech remotely on Thursday, a source told Yahoo Finance.

But who ultimately shows up from Trump's orbit — and what they say once touching down — could set the tone on US international relations right out of the gate. If a delegate arrives at Davos days after Trump takes actions that could weigh on the economic growth of foreign countries and then aims to explain the actions, best believe the inevitable headlines may not be so market-friendly.

—

Brian Sozzi is Yahoo Finance's Executive Editor. Follow Sozzi on X @BrianSozzi, Instagram, and on LinkedIn. Tips on stories? Email brian.sozzi@yahoofinance.com. Three times each week, Sozzi fields insight-filled conversations with the biggest names in business and markets on Yahoo Finance's Opening Bid podcast. Find more episodes on our video hub. Watch on your preferred streaming service. Or listen and subscribe on Apple Podcasts, Spotify, or wherever you find your favorite podcasts.

Click here for in-depth analysis of the latest stock market news and events moving stock prices

Read the latest financial and business news from Yahoo Finance

View Comments

Next I will provide you some predictions of stock price movement probabilities and the corresponding analysis by others in the previous rounds.
Note that others' predictions may indicate that they have some other information about the stock price. A high prediction may indicate that they have some positive information about the stock, while a low prediction may indicate that they have some megative information about the stock.
Also note that there are multiple rounds of precitions, demonstrating the trend of others' beliefs.
Please take these information into consideration when prediction the stock price movement probabilities.
Previous predictions:
Round: 0
Model: openai/gpt-4o-mini, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.55, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.45, Reasoning: The news discusses the upcoming World Economic Forum in Davos, where significant discussions around economic policies, tariffs, and AI are expected. While the focus is on various sectors and companies, the mention of potential volatility in the markets and the uncertainty surrounding Trump's policies could create a cautious sentiment among investors. However, Apple Inc. (AAPL) is generally viewed as a strong company with a solid market position, which may mitigate some negative impacts. Given the mixed signals from the news, I estimate a slightly higher probability of the stock price rising due to Apple's resilience and strong fundamentals, but also acknowledge the potential for a decline due to market volatility and external factors.
Model: google/gemini-2.0-flash-001, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.4, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.6, Reasoning: The news article primarily focuses on Jim Cramer's commentary on various topics, including Mark Zuckerberg's criticism of Apple's innovation since Steve Jobs' death. While Cramer defends Apple, the negative sentiment expressed by Zuckerberg, a prominent figure, could potentially impact investor perception. However, the article also highlights Apple's strong position and hedge fund interest. The overall impact is mixed, with potential for both positive and negative reactions. The article also mentions Cramer's comments on broader economic issues like interest rates and California wildfires, which could indirectly affect market sentiment but are not directly related to Apple's performance. Given the mixed signals, I'm assigning a slightly higher probability to a stock price fall due to the negative comments about innovation, but the overall impact is likely to be moderate.
Model: google/gemini-flash-1.5, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.45, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.55, Reasoning: The news highlights the significant institutional ownership (61%) of Apple stock. While high institutional ownership can be seen as positive, indicating confidence from large investors, it also presents a risk.  Large institutional investors selling simultaneously could trigger a significant price drop.  The news also mentions recent insider sales, which is a negative signal. However, the article lacks specific details about the volume or timing of these sales, making it difficult to quantify their impact.  The overall tone is somewhat neutral, acknowledging both the potential upside and downside risks associated with high institutional ownership.  Given the lack of strongly positive or negative information beyond the inherent risk of concentrated institutional ownership, the probabilities are assigned relatively close to even.
Model: deepseek/deepseek-chat-v3-0324, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.55, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.45, Reasoning: The news highlights that institutional investors own 61% of Apple's shares, which can lead to significant price movements based on their trading decisions. Institutional ownership is generally seen as a positive indicator due to their access to capital and research capabilities, but it also introduces vulnerability to large-scale sell-offs. The top 25 shareholders hold 41% of the business, indicating concentrated ownership that could amplify market reactions. Recent insider sales might signal caution, but the overall insider ownership is under 1%, limiting its impact. The general public holds 37%, which is substantial but not enough to counter institutional influence. Given these factors, the stock could experience volatility, but the strong institutional backing and historical performance suggest a balanced outlook.
Model: meta-llama/llama-4-scout, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.45, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.55, Reasoning: The news discusses various market-moving topics at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, including Trump's policies, tariffs, AI, and crypto. Apple Inc. (AAPL) is not directly mentioned in the news. However, the overall tone suggests potential market volatility due to various uncertainties. Given that AAPL is part of the 'Magnificent 7' stocks mentioned as looking 'top-heavy,' there might be a cautious outlook. However, without direct mention or specific catalysts for AAPL, the probabilities are relatively balanced but lean slightly towards a cautious stance due to general market conditions.
Model: meta-llama/llama-3.3-70b-instruct, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.45, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.55, Reasoning: The news article discusses Jim Cramer's comments on Apple Inc. (AAPL) and Mark Zuckerberg's recent interview on the Joe Rogan Experience podcast. Cramer criticized Zuckerberg's statement that Apple hasn't innovated since Steve Jobs' death, calling it 'ill-advised' and 'one of the most offensive interviews' he's heard. However, the article also mentions that Cramer's comments were part of a broader discussion on various topics, including the California wildfires, interest rates, and the insurance industry. Given the mixed tone of the article and the lack of directly bearish or bullish statements from Cramer, the impact on Apple's stock price is likely to be neutral. Nevertheless, the criticism from Zuckerberg and Cramer's response may lead to a slight increase in uncertainty and volatility, which could negatively impact the stock price. Therefore, I estimate a slightly higher probability of the stock price falling than rising.
Model: qwen/qwen-turbo, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.3, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.4, Reasoning: The financial news covers multiple macroeconomic and geopolitical factors including Trump policies, tariffs, AI developments, and cryptocurrency trends. These factors significantly influence the stock market, especially large market-cap stocks like those in the 'Magnificent 7' (including Apple Inc.). The news hints at market volatility and increased uncertainty, which could impact investor sentiment negatively. However, Apple Inc., being a strong, diversified company, might mitigate some of these impacts.
Round: 1
Model: openai/gpt-4o-mini, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.52, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.48, Reasoning: The news discusses the upcoming World Economic Forum in Davos, where significant discussions around economic policies, tariffs, and AI are expected. While there are concerns about market volatility and uncertainty surrounding Trump's policies, Apple Inc. is generally viewed as a strong company with solid fundamentals. The mention of the 'Magnificent 7' stocks looking top-heavy suggests caution, but Apple's resilience and strong institutional backing may mitigate some negative impacts. Overall, the mixed signals lead to a slightly higher probability of the stock price rising, but the potential for a decline due to market volatility is also acknowledged.
Model: google/gemini-2.0-flash-001, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.45, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.55, Reasoning: The news focuses on Jim Cramer's reaction to Mark Zuckerberg's criticism of Apple, stating that Apple hasn't innovated since Steve Jobs' death. While Cramer defends Apple, the fact that a prominent figure like Zuckerberg made such a statement could negatively impact investor sentiment. However, Cramer's defense and the article's mention of Apple's strong position and hedge fund interest provide some counterweight. The previous rounds of predictions show a mixed sentiment, with some models leaning towards a price fall due to the negative comments, while others are more neutral. Considering the negative sentiment from Zuckerberg and the mixed reactions from previous predictions, I believe there's a slightly higher chance of the stock price falling, but not drastically so, as Cramer defends Apple and the company has strong fundamentals.
Model: google/gemini-flash-1.5, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.4, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.6, Reasoning: The news highlights the significant institutional ownership (61%) of Apple stock. This is a double-edged sword. While it suggests confidence from large investors, it also increases the risk of a sharp price drop if these institutions decide to sell simultaneously.  The mention of recent insider sales adds to the negative sentiment, although the lack of specifics limits the impact assessment.  The overall picture is one of potential volatility, with the risk of a price fall outweighing the potential for a rise, given the concentrated ownership and the negative signal from insider selling.  The previous predictions show a range of opinions, with a slight leaning towards a price fall in several models. Considering the inherent risk associated with high institutional ownership and the lack of strong positive catalysts, a slightly higher probability is assigned to a price fall.
Model: deepseek/deepseek-chat-v3-0324, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.5, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.5, Reasoning: The news highlights that institutional investors own 61% of Apple's shares, which can lead to significant price movements based on their trading decisions. Institutional ownership is generally seen as a positive indicator due to their access to capital and research capabilities, but it also introduces vulnerability to large-scale sell-offs. The top 25 shareholders hold 41% of the business, indicating concentrated ownership that could amplify market reactions. Recent insider sales might signal caution, but the overall insider ownership is under 1%, limiting its impact. The general public holds 37%, which is substantial but not enough to counter institutional influence. Given these factors, the stock could experience volatility, but the strong institutional backing and historical performance suggest a balanced outlook.
Model: meta-llama/llama-4-scout, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.48, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.52, Reasoning: The news discusses the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, where various market-moving topics will be addressed, including Trump's policies, tariffs, AI, and crypto. Apple Inc. (AAPL) is part of the 'Magnificent 7' stocks mentioned as looking 'top-heavy,' suggesting potential market volatility. However, Apple is a strong company with solid fundamentals, which may mitigate some negative impacts. The news does not directly mention Apple or provide specific catalysts for the stock. Given the mixed signals and general market conditions, I estimate a slightly higher probability of the stock price rising due to Apple's resilience, but also acknowledge the potential for a decline due to market volatility and external factors.
Model: meta-llama/llama-3.3-70b-instruct, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.48, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.52, Reasoning: The news article discusses Jim Cramer's comments on Apple Inc. (AAPL) and Mark Zuckerberg's recent interview on the Joe Rogan Experience podcast. Cramer criticized Zuckerberg's statement that Apple hasn't innovated since Steve Jobs' death, calling it 'ill-advised' and 'one of the most offensive interviews' he's heard. However, the article also mentions that Cramer's comments were part of a broader discussion on various topics, including the California wildfires, interest rates, and the insurance industry. Given the mixed tone of the article and the lack of directly bearish or bullish statements from Cramer, the impact on Apple's stock price is likely to be neutral. Nevertheless, the criticism from Zuckerberg and Cramer's response may lead to a slight increase in uncertainty and volatility, which could negatively impact the stock price. Considering the previous predictions from other models, which show a range of opinions on the potential impact of the news, I will take a balanced approach and estimate the probabilities based on the overall sentiment and potential market reaction.
Model: qwen/qwen-turbo, Prediction of stock price rising: 0.4, Prediction of stock price falling: 0.6, Reasoning: The financial news covers multiple macroeconomic and geopolitical factors including Trump policies, tariffs, AI developments, and cryptocurrency trends. These factors significantly influence the stock market, especially large market-cap stocks like those in the 'Magnificent 7' (including Apple Inc.). The news hints at market volatility and increased uncertainty, which could impact investor sentiment negatively. However, Apple Inc., being a strong, diversified company, might mitigate some of these impacts.


Now give your prediction about the probability of the stock price of the relevant company rising or falling. Format your response in JSON format and include the following information as follows: 
{ 
"reasoning": "[Summarize your analysis and reasoning process here]", 
"company_name": "[Company Name indicating the name of the company]", 
"company_symbol": "[Company Symbol indicating the stock symbol of the company]",

}

However, Apple is a strong company with solid fundamentals, which may mitigate some negative impacts.
